RMPTitle: Food Safety and Env Compliance Man

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Morada Produce has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Morada Produce, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Morada Produce has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration          Anhydrous Ammonia               34,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations a

s well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Morada Produce operates a commercial packing and storage facility for cherries, walnuts, bell peppers, and onions in Stockton, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system which provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(1) Palletizing Room

(1) Shipping Cooler

(4) Ammonia Cold Storage Rooms 

(1) Precool Room

(2) Receiving Coolers

(2) Fumigation Rooms

(3) Cherry Hydrocoolers

(1) Receiving Hydrocooler



1.2.2 Facility Location



Morada Produce is located at 500 N Jack Tone Rd. Stockton, CA 95215. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 37.977401, -121.147327. The facility is located approximately 5.5 miles east of state highway 99 and 1.5 miles south of state highway 26 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agricultural land.



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area with a 0.2% annual chance  of flooding. 



Morada Produce is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Morada Produce has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.



1.2.3 Description of Covered Process



Each of the ammonia refrigerated zones are equipped with evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is containe

d within a central refrigeration machinery room. Seasonally, Morada Produce rents three (3) high-side ammonia trailers to add additional refrigeration capacity for the cherry season. A partial list of permanent system components includes:

(3) High Pressure Receivers

(2) Suction Accumulators

(2) Dump Traps

(4) Frick Screw Compressors

(1) Emergency Control Box

(1) Machinery Room Ventilation System

(1) Ammonia Diffusion Tank

(22) Flooded Accumulators

(9) Ceiling Suspended Air-Cooling Evaporators

(19) Bunker Mounted Air-Cooling Evaporators

(7) Hydrocooler Coils



Process Chemistry



High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are each equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulators

The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators/hydrocoolers. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators/hydrocoolers. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators/hydrocoolers is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the suction accumulators. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid an

d vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Hydrocoolers

The purpose of the hydrocoolers is to remove heat from water which is used to precool fresh fruit. The hydrocoolers receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the hydrocoolers and is returned to the supplying vessels. Under normal conditions, the hydrocoolers contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Suction Accumulators

The purpose of the suction accumulators is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The suction accumulators receive vapor from the flooded accumulators and separate any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the suction accumulators drains by gravity into the dump traps. The suction accumulators are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the suction accumulators contain low pressure vapor ammonia.



Dump Traps

The purpose of the dump traps is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrige

ration system back to the high pressure receivers. The dump traps receive liquid from the suction accumulators. Once the liquid level in the dump traps reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valves are energized for a period of time causing the dump traps to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into the high pressure receivers. Under normal conditions the dump traps can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporator to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the suction accumulators and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condensers

The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators/hydrocoolers to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection System

The machinery room is equipped with two (2) ammonia detectors. A low-level sensor provides low concentration detection and alerts personnel if the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm. If the concentration reaches 75 ppm, the emergency ventilation system wi

ll be activated. A high-level detector provides high concentration detection and will shut the system down if the concentration exceeds 20,000 ppm. Additional ammonia detectors are installed in each refrigerated room and in the relief vent line. These detectors will activate alarms at 25 ppm.



Emergency Control Box

The emergency control box was installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2 and the Fire Code at the time of construction. The control box contains three (3) valves.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. 

The emergency control box is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank; 

The relief valve discharge termination pipe is equipped with a vent line sensor which will notify plant personnel if a release occurs.



Diffusion Tank

The refrigeration system is equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tank. The ammonia diffusion tank is 8' dia. x 16' high (6,016 gallon capacity). At a water level of 13'-6", the tank contains 5,076 gallons of water which exceeds th

e quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.



Screw Compressor Safety Devices

Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switch

The suction accumulators are each equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valves (King Valves)

The high pressure receivers are each equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.

Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)



The principal entrance to the machinery room is equipped with an emergen

cy refrigeration switch that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency using the hammer next to the switch to break the switch glass.



1.2.4 Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Morada Produce consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Morada Produce is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Morada Produce has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Morada Produce facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration contractor (Schrader Mechanical monitors the ammonia refrigeration process frequently and keeps active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia.



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Morada Produce has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Morada Produce's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Eme

rgency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Morada Produce has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Morada Produce continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Morada Produce's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Morada Produce's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Morada Produce has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazar

d analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Morada Produce has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Morada Produce now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Morada Produce employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Morada Produce will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
